revision.comment: Add that several of the names given for Ocheanids, are also names given for Nereids.
revision.text:
{{short description|Wikimedia list article}} [[File:Les Oceanides Les Naiades de la mer.jpg|thumb|300px|''Les Oceanides Les Naiades de la mer''. [[Gustave Doré]], 1860s]] In [[Greek mythology]], the [[nymph]] daughters of the [[Titan (mythology)|Titan]] [[Oceanus]] (Ocean), were known collectively as the [[Oceanid]]s. Four ancient sources give lists of names of Oceanids. The oldest, and longest such list, given by the late 8th–early 7th century BC Greek poet [[Hesiod]], names 41 Oceanids.[[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+337 349–361]: Peitho, Admete, Ianthe, Electra, Doris, Prymno, Urania, Hippo, Clymene, Rhodea, Callirrhoe, Zeuxo, Clytie, Idyia, Pasithoe, Plexaura, Galaxaura, Dione, Melobosis, Thoe, Polydora, Cerceis, Pluto, Perseis, Ianeira, Acaste, Xanthe, Petraea, Menestho, Europa, Metis, Eurynome, Telesto, Chryseis, Asia, Calypso, Eudora, Tyche, Amphirho, Ocyrrhoe, and Styx. Hesiod goes on to say that these "are the eldest ... but there are many besides" and that there were "three thousand" Oceanids,[[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+337 362–364]. a number interpreted as meaning "innumerable".Hard, [https://books.google.com/books?id=r1Y3xZWVlnIC&pg=PA40 p. 40]. While some of these names, such as [[Peitho]], [[Metis (mythology)|Metis]] and [[Tyche]], certainly reflected existing traditions, many were probably mere poetic inventions.West 1966, p. 260; Hard, [https://books.google.com/books?id=r1Y3xZWVlnIC&pg=PA41 p. 41]. The probably nearly as old [[Homeric Hymns|''Homeric Hymn to Demeter'']] lists 21 names, 16 of which match those given by Hesiod,[[Homeric Hymns|''Homeric Hymn to Demeter'']], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0013.tlg002.perseus-eng1:398-448 418–423]. The matching names are: Acaste, Admete, Callirhoe, Calypso, Chryseis, Electra, Galaxaura, Ianeira, Ianthe, Melobosis, Ocyrhoe, Pluto, Rhodea, Styx, Tyche, and Urania. The additions are: Iache, Leucippe, Melite, Phaeno, and Rhodope. and were probably taken directly from there.West 1966, p. 260; Evelyn-White, note to [[Homeric Hymns|''Homeric Hymn to Demeter'']] [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0013.tlg002.perseus-eng1:398-448 418]. The roughly contemporary (? c. 1st century AD) Greek mythographer [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]] and the Latin mythographer [[Hyginus]] also give lists of Oceanids. Apollodorus gives a list containing 7 names,Asia, Styx, Electra, Doris, Eurynome, Amphitrite, and Metis ([http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.2.2 1.2.2]). as well as mentioning 5 other Oceanids elsewhere.[[Callirrhoe (Oceanid)|Callirhoe]] ([http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:2.5.10 2.5.10]), [[Idyia]] ([http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.9.23 1.9.23]), [[Melia (consort of Inachus)|Melia]] ([http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:2.1.1 2.1.1]), [[Meliboea]] ([http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:3.8.1 3.8.1]), and [[Pleione (mythology)|Pleione]] ([http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:3.10.1 3.10.1]). Of these 12 names, 8 match Hesiod.The matching names are: Asia, Callirhoe, Doris, Electra, Eurynome, Idyia, Metis, and Styx. The additions are: Amphitrite, Melia, Meliboea, and Pleione. Hyginus, at the beginning of his ''[[Fabulae]]'', lists 16 names, while elsewhere he gives the names of 10 others.Hyginus lists 17 names, but one is unintelligible: Hestyaea, Melite, Ianthe, Admete, Stilbo, Pasiphae, Polyxo, Eurynome, Euagoreis, Rhodope, Lyris, Clytia, , Clitemneste, Mentis, Menippe, Argia (''[[Fabulae]]'' Th. 6; Smith and Trzaskoma, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA95 p. 95]). The other 10 names are: Philyra (''Fab.'' 138; Smith and Trzaskoma, p. 146), Merope (''Fab.'' 154; Smith and Trzaskoma, p. 150), Persis (''Fab.'' 156; Smith and Trzaskoma, p. 150), Ida, Amalthea, and Adrasteia (''Fab.'' 182; Smith and Trzaskoma, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA158 p. 158]), Pleione (''Fab.'' 192; Smith and Trzaskoma, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA162 p. 162]), Ephyra (''Fab.'' 275.6; Smith and Trzaskoma, p. 181), Aethra (''[[De astronomica|Astronomica]]'' 2.21). Of these 26 names, only 9 are found in Hesiod, the ''Homeric Hymn'', or Apollodorus. Many other names are given in other ancient sources. The names of the Oceanids are of different types.For a detailed treatment of many of the Hesiodic names see West 1966, pp. 264 ff. The Oceanids were the nymphs of springs,West 1966, p. 259 ll. 337-70; Caldwell, p. 48; Most, p. 31. and some of the names apparently reflect this aquatic connection, with some perhaps being the names of actual springs.West 1966, p. 260; Evelyn-White, note to Hes. ''Th.'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0020.tlg001.perseus-eng1:337-370 346]. Other names have no apparent connection with water. Some, consistent with the Oceanids' function, as specified by Hesiod, of having "youths in their keeping" (i.e. being ''kourotrophoi''),West 1966, p. 263 346. '''κουρίξουσι'''; [[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+337 347]. represent things which parents might hope to be bestowed upon their children: Plouto ("Wealth"), Tyche ("Good Fortune"), Idyia ("Knowing"), and Metis ("Wisdom").Fowler 2013, [https://books.google.com/books?id=scd8AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA13 p. 13]. Others appear to be geographical [[eponyms]], such as Europa, Asia, Ephyra ([[Corinth]]), and Rhodos ([[Rhodes]]).Fowler 2013, [https://books.google.com/books?id=scd8AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA13 pp. 13–16]. Several of the names given for Ocheanids, are also names given for [[Nereid]]s, the fifty sea nymphs who were the daughters of the sea god [[Nereus]] and the Oceanid [[Doris (mythology)|Doris]]. ==List== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:left" |+Named Oceanids ! rowspan="2" |Name ! colspan="5" |Sources ! rowspan="2" |Notes |- ! Hes.[[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+349 349–361]. !''Hom. Hymn'' [[Homeric Hymns|''Homeric Hymn to Demeter'']], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0013.tlg002.perseus-eng1:398-448 418–423]. ! Ap.[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.2.2 1.2.2], except where otherwise indicated. ! Hyg.[[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' Th. 6 (Smith and Trzaskoma, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA95 p. 95]), except where otherwise indicated. ! Others |- |[[Acaste]] | ✓ || ✓ || || || | |- |[[Admete (Oceanid)|Admete]] | ✓ || ✓ || || ✓ || | |- |[[Adrasteia]] | || || || ✓[[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA158 182]|| ||[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.1.6 1.1.6] makes the nymphs Adrasteia and [[Ida (nurse of Zeus)|Ida]], the nurses of [[Zeus]], daughters of [[Melissus of Crete|Melisseus]], leader of the [[Korybantes|Kuretes]] of [[Crete]] |- | [[Aethra (Greek mythology)|Aethra]] | || || || ✓[[Hyginus]], ''[[De astronomica|Astronomica]]'' [http://www.theoi.com/Text/HyginusAstronomica2.html#21 2.21]||[[Pherecydes of Leros]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=j0nRE4C2WBgC&pg=PA322 fr. 90c Fowler]; [[Ovid]], ''[[Fasti (poem)|Fasti]]'' [https://archive.org/stream/ovidsfasti00oviduoft#page/272/mode/2up 5.171] | |- | [[Aetna (nymph)|Aetna]] | || || || ||[[Stephanus of Byzantium]], s.v. [https://archive.org/stream/stephanibyzanti00meingoog#page/n508/mode/1up Παλιχη] | |- |[[Amalthea (mythology)|Amalthea]] | || || || ✓[[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA158 182]; an outdated Latin text of Hyginus' ''Fabulae'' has ''Althaea'', see Smith and Trzaskoma, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA191 p. 191 endnote to 182]; West 1983, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Sp5fAAAAMAAJ&q=Althaea+Hyg.+Fab.+182&dq=Althaea+Hyg.+Fab.+182&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwidxreOrPjOAhXMsh4KHboABJQQ6AEIHDAA p. 133].||[https://archive.org/stream/scholiagraecain05dindgoog#page/n195/mode/1up Schol. ''ad Hom. II.'' 21.194] |Usually not an Oceanid e.g. [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:2.7.5 2.7.5] |- | Amphirho | ✓ || || || || | |- |[[Amphitrite]] | || || ✓+Also [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.4.5 1.4.5]|| || |The name of a [[Nereid]] at [[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'', [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+243 243], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+254 254], and [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.2.7 1.2.7] |- | [[Argia (mythology)|Argia]]
or Argea | || || || ✓+Also [[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA147 143]|| ||Mother of [[Phoroneus]], by [[Inachus]], at [[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA147 143], however the mother is an Oceanid named [[Melia (consort of Inachus)|Melia]] at [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:2.1.1 2.1.1] |- |[[Asia (mythology)|Asia]] | ✓ || || ✓ || ||[[Andron|Andron of Halicarnassus]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=j0nRE4C2WBgC&pg=PA42 fr. 7 Fowler] = ''[[FGrHist]]'' 10 F 7 (mother is Pompholyge)Fowler 2001, [https://books.google.com/books?id=j0nRE4C2WBgC&pg=PA42 p. 42]; Fowler 2013, [https://books.google.com/books?id=scd8AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA13 p. 13]; Bouzek and Graninger, [https://books.google.com/books?id=cMcvCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA12 p. 12]. Fowler 2013, p. 15, calls Pompholyge, a name found nowhere else, an ''ad hoc'' invention. | The name of a [[Nereid]] at [[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA95 Th. 8] |- |[[Asterodia]] | || || || ||Scholia on [[Apollonius of Rhodes]], ''[[Argonautica]]'' 3.242 ([https://archive.org/stream/bub_gb_oBI-AAAAcAAJ#page/n267/mode/1up Parisian], [https://archive.org/stream/bub_gb_oBI-AAAAcAAJ#page/n576/mode/1up Florentine]). | |- |Asterope | || || || ||[[Stephanus of Byzantium]], s.v. [https://archive.org/stream/stephanibyzanti00meingoog#page/n74/mode/1up ''Akragantes''] | |- |[[Beroe (mythology)|Beroe]] | || || || ||[[Virgil]], ''[[Georgics]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:latinLit:phi0690.phi002.perseus-eng1:4.333-4.386 4.341]; cf. [[Nonnus]], ''[[Dionysiaca]]'' [https://archive.org/stream/dionysiaca03nonnuoft#page/206/mode/2up 41.153] |The name of a [[Nereid]] at [[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA95 Th. 8] |- |[[Callirrhoe (Oceanid)|Callirhoe]] | ✓ || ✓ || ✓[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:2.5.10 2.5.10]|| || | |- | Calypso | ✓ || ✓ || || || || The name of a [[Nereid]] at [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.2.7 1.2.7]; "probably not" the same as the [[Calypso (mythology)|Calypso]] who was the lover of [[Odysseus]]Caldwell, p. 49 n. 359, see also West 1966, p. 267 359. {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Passiflora'' species}} This is a list of species in the botanical genus ''[[Passiflora]]''. There are in excess of 550 species mostly occurring in the [[Neotropics]], but with a few species in the [[Nearctic]] and some others in Asia and Australasia. The list is incomplete. [[File:Passiflora alata1MTFL.jpg|thumb|Winged-stem passion flower (''[[Passiflora alata]]'')]] [[File:Passiflora aurantia3.jpg|thumb|''[[Passiflora aurantia]]'']] [[File:Passiflora biflora3.jpg|thumb|Two flowered passion flower (''[[Passiflora biflora]]'')]] [[File:Passiflora citrina - D8-04-7243.jpg|thumb|Lemon-yellow passion flower, ''[[Passiflora citrina]]'']] [[File:Passiflora edulis.jpg|thumb|Passionfruit (''[[Passiflora edulis]]'')]] [[File:P foetida flower.jpg|thumb|Wild water lemon ''[[Passiflora foetida]]'']] [[File:Passiflora glandulosa - Suriname.jpg|thumb|''[[Passiflora glandulosa]]'']] [[File:Starr 980807-1612 Passiflora laurifolia.jpg|thumb|Water lemon (''[[Passiflora laurifolia]]'')]] [[File:Passiflora Edulis - fruit.JPG|thumb|Sweet granadilla (''[[Passiflora ligularis]]'')]] [[File:Passiflora racemosa hy.jpg|thumb|''[[Passiflora racemosa]]'']] [[File:Passiflora rubra.jpg|thumb|''[[Passiflora rubra]]'']] [[File:PassionFlowerCostaRica.JPG|thumb|''[[Passiflora pittieri]]'']] ==Species== * ‡ ''[[Passiflora actinia]]'' Hook. * ''[[Passiflora adenopoda]]'' DC. * ''[[Passiflora affinis]]'' Engelm. * ‡ ''[[Passiflora alata]]'' Curtis – winged-stem passion flower, ''ouvaca'' * ¶ ''[[Passiflora altebilobata]]'' Hemsl. * ‡ ''[[Passiflora ambigua]]'' Hemsl. ex Hook.f. * ''[[Passiflora amethystina]]'' J.C.Mikan * ‡ ''[[Passiflora ampullacea]]'' Harms * ''[[Passiflora andina]]'' (H.Karst.) page.title: List of Ramsar sites in the Republic of Ireland

revision.text:
This '''list of Ramsar sites in the Republic of Ireland''' includes [[wetlands]] that are considered to be of international importance under the [[Ramsar Convention]]. Ireland currently has 45 sites designated as "Wetlands of International Importance" with a surface area of {{convert|66,994|ha|km2}}.{{cite web|title=Ramsar List|url=http://www.ramsar.org/pdf/sitelist.pdf|publisher=Ramsar.org|accessdate=1 April 2013}}{{cite web|title=The Annotated Ramsar List: Ireland|url=http://www.ramsar.org/cda/fr/ramsar-pubs-notes-anno-ireland/main/ramsar/1-30-168%5E16569_4000_1__|publisher=Ramsar.org|accessdate=1 April 2013}} For a full list of all Ramsar sites worldwide, see [[List of Ramsar wetlands of international importance]]. {{GeoGroup}}{{-}} == List of Ramsar Sites == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" | Name ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" width="15%" | Location ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" | Area (km2) ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" width="12%" | Designated ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" class="unsortable" | Description ! style="background-color:{{RAMSAR color}}" class="unsortable" | Image |- | [[Baldoyle Bay]] | Dublin

page.title: List of Superfund sites in Ohio

revision.text:
This is a '''list of Superfund sites in Ohio''' designated under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) environmental law. The CERCLA federal law of 1980 authorized the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) to create a list of [[Pollution|polluted]] locations requiring a long-term response to clean up hazardous material contaminations.P.L. 96-510, {{USC|42|9601|9675}}), December 11, 1980. These locations are known as [[Superfund]] sites, and are placed on the [[National Priorities List]] (NPL). The NPL guides the EPA in "determining which sites warrant further investigation" for [[environmental remediation]]. As of November 29, 2010, there were 34 Superfund sites on the National Priorities List in [[Ohio]].{{cite web| url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/npl/ |title=National Priorities List |publisher=United States Enivironmental Protection Agency |accessdate=January 20, 2011}} Eight additional sites are currently proposed for entry on the list. Seven sites have been cleaned up and removed from the list. ==Superfund sites== :{{legend2|#fcf75e|Proposed for addition to National Priorities List|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} :{{legend2|#d0f0c0|Deleted from National Priorities List|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !CERCLIS ID!!Name !Town!!County!!Proposed!!Listed!!Construction

Alternative sites are locations that have been found to be polluted enough to be listed on the [[National Priorities List]], but are cleaned up through other methods without formal listing.{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/compliance/cleanup/superfund/saa.html |title=Superfund Alternative Approach |publisher=EPA |accessdate=April 23, 2010}} These are not "Superfund" sites since they do not go {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Trametes'' species}} '''''Trametes''''' is a genus of [[polypore|poroid]] fungi in the family [[Polyporaceae]]. {{As of|2017|December}}, [[Index Fungorum]] accepts 195 species of ''Trametes'':<ref name="CoL-Fungorum 2018"/>

<ref name="Ryvarden 2003">{{cite journal |author1=Ryvarden, L. |author2=Iturriaga, T. |year=2003 |title=Studies in neotropical polypores 10. New polypores from Venezuela |journal=Mycologia |volume=95 |issue=6 |pages=1066–1077 |doi=}}</ref>

(Higher Basidiomycetes) with estimation of their medicinal source potential |journal=International Journal of Medicinal Mushrooms |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=307–319 |pmid=22577980 |doi=10.1615/IntJMedMushr.v14.i3.70}}</ref>

revision.comment: RU Cas suspected NOT to be variable
/* Moon dust fountains and electrostatic levitation */
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Moondust|the Commodore 64 video game|Moondust (video game)|the album by The Pillows|Moondust (album)|the psychoactive drug|Phencyclidine}} {{use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} [[File:Apollo 11 bootprint.jpg|thumb|Bootprint on lunar soil]] [[File:Lunar Regolith 70050 from Apollo 17 in National Museum of Natural History.jpg|thumb|Regolith collected during [[Apollo 17]] mission]]
'''Lunar soil''' is the [[grain size|fine fraction]] of the [[regolith]] found on the [[selenography|surface]] of the [[Moon]]. Its properties can differ significantly from those of terrestrial [[soil]]. The physical properties of lunar soil are primarily the result of mechanical disintegration of [[basaltic]] and [[anorthositic]] rock, caused by continuous [[impact event|meteoric impacts]] and [[sputtering|bombardment]] by interstellar charged atomic particles over years. The process is largely one of [[Weathering#Physical weathering|mechanical weathering]] in which the particles are ground to finer and finer size over time. This situation contrasts fundamentally to terrestrial soil formation, mediated by the presence of molecular [[oxygen]] (O<sub>2</sub>), humidity, atmospheric wind, and a robust array of contributing biological processes. Some have argued that the term ''soil'' is not correct in reference to the [[Moon]] because on [[Earth]], soil is defined as having [[organic matter|organic]] content, whereas the Moon has none. However, standard usage among lunar scientists is to ignore that distinction.
The term ''lunar soil'' is often used interchangeably with '''''lunar regolith''''', but typically refers to only the finer fraction of regolith, that which is composed of grains [[centimeter|1 cm]] in diameter or less.<ref>{{cite book|last=Heiken|last2=Vanniman |last3=French|lastauthoramp=yes|title=Lunar Sourcebook|date=1991|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=978-0-521-33444-0|pages=756}}</ref> '''Lunar dust''' generally connotes even finer materials than lunar soil. There is no official definition of what size fraction constitutes "dust"; some place the cutoff at less than 50 [[micrometre|μm]] in diameter, while others at less than 10 μm.
==Formation processes== [[File:Apollo 17 orange soil.jpg|thumb|right|Orange soil found on Apollo 17, the result of volcanic glass beads]]{{Further|Geology of the Moon}}
The major processes involved in the formation of lunar soil are: *[[Comminution]]: mechanical breaking of rocks and minerals into smaller particles by meteorite and [[micrometeorite]] impact; *[[Agglutination (biology)|Agglutination]]: welding of mineral and rock fragments together by micrometeorite-impact-produced glass; *[[Solar wind]] spallation and implantation: sputtering caused by impacts of ions and high energy particles.
These processes not only form lunar soil, they also continue to change the physical and optical properties of the soil over time; this process is known as [[space weathering]]. In addition, fire fountaining, whereby volcanic lava is lofted and cools into small glass beads before falling back to the surface, can create small but important deposits in some locations, such as the orange soil found at [[Shorty Crater]] in the [[Taurus-Littrow]] valley by [[Apollo 17]], and the green glass found at [[Hadley–Apennine (Moon)|Hadley-Apennine]] by [[Apollo 15]]. Deposits of volcanic beads are also thought to be the origin of Dark Mantle Deposits (DMD) in other locations around the Moon.<ref name="DMD">{{cite web|title=Explosive Volcanic Eruptions on the Moon|url=http://www.psrd.hawaii.edu/Feb97/MoonVolcanics.html}}</ref>
==Mineralogy and composition== Lunar soil is composed of various types of particles including rock fragments, mono-mineralic fragments, and various kinds of glasses including [[agglutination (biology)|agglutinate]] particles and volcanic and impact spherules. The agglutinates form at the lunar surface by micrometeorite impacts that cause small-scale melting which fuses adjacent materials together with tiny specks of metallic iron (Fe<sup>0</sup>) embedded in each dust particle’s glassy shell.
Over time, material is mixed both vertically and horizontally (a process known as "gardening") by impact processes. However, the contribution of material from great distances is relatively minor, such that the soil composition at any given location largely reflects the local bedrock composition.
There are two profound differences in the chemistry of lunar regolith and soil from terrestrial materials. The first is that the Moon is very dry. As a result, those minerals with water as part of their structure such as [[clay]], [[mica]], and [[amphiboles]] are totally absent from the Moon. The second difference is that lunar regolith and crust are chemically [[redox|reduced]], rather than being significantly [[oxidized]] like the Earth's crust. In the case of the regolith, this is due in part to the constant bombardment of the lunar surface with protons (i.e. hydrogen (H) nuclei) from the solar wind. One consequence is that iron on the Moon is found in the metallic 0 and +2 oxidation states, whereas on Earth iron is found primarily in the +2 and +3 oxidation states.<gallery> Image:Composition_of_lunar_soil.svg|Relative concentration of various elements on the lunar surface Image:Moon_vs_earth_composition.svg|Relative concentration (in weight %) of various elements on lunar highlands, lunar lowlands and Earth </gallery>
==Properties== [[File:Ap16 rover.ogv|thumb|right|A short video of a [[lunar rover]] kicking up lunar regolith ([[Apollo 16]], 1972)]]
The significance of acquiring appropriate knowledge of lunar soil properties is great. The potential for construction of structures,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Naeye|first=Robert|title=NASA Scientists Pioneer Method for Making Giant Lunar Telescopes|publisher=[[Goddard Space Flight Center]]|date=6 April 2008|url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/goddard/news/topstory/2008/lunar_telescopes.html|accessdate=27 February 2011}}</ref> ground transportation networks, and waste disposal systems, to name a few examples, will depend on real-world experimental data obtained from testing lunar soil samples. The load-carrying capability of the soil is an important parameter in the design of such structures on Earth.
Due to myriad meteorite impacts (with velocities in the range of 20 km/s), the lunar surface is covered with a thin layer of dust. The dust is electrically charged and sticks to any surface it comes in contact with. The density of lunar regolith is about 1.5 g/cm<sup>3</sup>.<ref>[https://curator.jsc.nasa.gov/lunar/letss/regolith.pdf Lunar Regolith @NASA]</ref> The soil becomes very dense beneath the top layer of regolith. Other factors which may affect the properties of lunar soil include large [[temperature]] [[Differential thermal analysis|differentials]], the presence of a hard [[vacuum]], and the absence of a significant lunar [[magnetic field]] (thereby allowing charged solar wind particles to continuously hit the surface of the Moon).
==Moon dust fountains and electrostatic levitation== There is some evidence that the Moon may have a tenuous atmosphere of moving dust particles constantly leaping up from and falling back to the Moon's surface, giving rise to a "dust atmosphere" that looks static but is composed of dust particles in constant motion. The term "Moon fountain" has been used to describe this effect by analogy with the stream of molecules of water in a fountain following a ballistic trajectory while appearing static due to the constancy of the stream. According to a model proposed in 2005 by the Laboratory for Extraterrestrial Physics at [[NASA]]'s [[Goddard Space Flight Center]],<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Lunar and Planetary Science XXXVI|date=2005|url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2005/pdf/1899.pdf|title=A Dynamic Fountain Model for Lunar Dust|first=Timothy J.|last=Stubbs|author2=Richard R. Vondrak|author3=William M. Farrell|lastauthoramp=yes}}</ref> this is caused by [[electrostatic levitation]]. On the daylit side of the Moon, solar [[ultraviolet]] and [[X-ray]] radiation is energetic enough to knock [[electron]]s out of atoms and molecules in the lunar soil. Positive charges build up until the tiniest particles of lunar dust (measuring 1 micrometre and smaller) are repelled from the surface and lofted anywhere from metres to kilometres high, with the smallest particles reaching the highest altitudes. Eventually they fall back toward the surface where the process is repeated. On the night side, the dust is negatively charged by electrons in the [[solar wind]]. Indeed, the fountain model suggests that the night side would achieve greater voltage differences than the day side, possibly launching dust particles to higher velocities and altitudes.<ref name="moonfountains">[https://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2005/30mar_moonfountains.htm Moon Fountains] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100319112529/http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2005/30mar_moonfountains.htm |date=19 March 2010 }}</ref> This effect could be further enhanced during the portion of the Moon's orbit where it passes through Earth's [[magnetotail]]; see [[Magnetic field of the Moon]] for more detail.<ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/topics/moonmars/features/magnetotail_080416.html NASA - The Moon and the Magnetotail]</ref> On the terminator there could be significant horizontal electric fields forming between the day and night areas, resulting in horizontal dust transport - a form of "moon storm".<ref name="moonfountains"/><ref name="moonstorms">[https://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2005/07dec_moonstorms.htm NASA - Moon Storms]</ref> [[File:Apollo 17 twilight ray sketch.jpg|thumb|Lunar "twilight rays" sketched by Apollo 17 astronauts]] This effect was anticipated in 1956 by science fiction author [[Hal Clement]] in his short story "Dust Rag", published in ''[[Astounding Science Fiction]]''.<ref name=moonfountains/> [[File:Moon Regolith in Moscow.JPG|thumb|A piece of [[regolith]] from [[Apollo 11]] presented to [[the Soviet Union]] and exhibited in the [[Memorial Museum of Astronautics]] in [[Moscow]]]] There is some evidence for this effect. In the early 1960s, [[Surveyor 7]]<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081015195451/http://www.livescience.com/space/scienceastronomy/080418-strange-moon.html Strange Things Happen at Full Moon|LiveScience]</ref> and several prior [[Surveyor spacecraft]] that soft-landed on the Moon returned photographs showing an unmistakable twilight glow low over the lunar horizon persisting after the Sun had set.<ref name=moonfountains/> Moreover, the distant horizon between land and sky did not look razor-sharp, as would have been expected in a vacuum where there was no atmospheric haze. Apollo 17 astronauts orbiting the Moon in 1972 repeatedly saw and sketched what they variously called "bands," "streamers" or "twilight rays" for about 10 seconds before lunar sunrise or lunar sunset. Such rays were also reported by astronauts aboard Apollo 8, 10, and 15. These may have been similar to [[crepuscular ray]]s on Earth.<ref name=moonfountains/>
Apollo 17 also placed an experiment on the Moon's surface called [[Apollo Lunar Surface Experiments Package|LEAM]], short for Lunar Ejecta and Meteorites. It was designed to look for dust kicked up by small meteoroids hitting the Moon's surface. It had three sensors that could record the speed, energy, and direction of tiny particles: one each pointing up, east, and west. LEAM saw a large number of particles every morning, mostly coming from the east or west—rather than above or below—and mostly slower than speeds expected for lunar ejecta. In addition, the experiment's temperature increased to near 100 degrees Celsius a few hours after each lunar sunrise, so the unit had to be turned off temporarily because it was overheating. It is speculated that this could have been a result of electrically-charged moondust sticking to LEAM, darkening its surface so the experiment package absorbed rather than reflected sunlight.<ref name=moonstorms/> However, scientists were unable to make a definite determination of the source of the problem, as LEAM operated only briefly before the Apollo program ended.<ref name=Dirt>[http://www.airspacemag.com/space/stronger-than-dirt-8944228/ Trudy E. Bell, ''Stronger Than Dirt'', [[Air & Space Smithsonian]], August/September 2006, pp. 46–53]</ref>
It is possible that these storms have been spotted from Earth: For centuries, there have been reports of strange glowing lights on the Moon, known as "[[Transient lunar phenomenon|Transient lunar phenomena]]" or TLPs. Some TLPs have been observed as momentary flashes—now generally accepted to be visible evidence of meteoroids impacting the lunar surface. But others have appeared as amorphous reddish or whitish glows or even as dusky hazy regions that change shape or disappear over seconds or minutes. These may have been a result of sunlight reflecting from suspended lunar dust.<ref name=moonstorms/>
==Harmful effects of lunar dust== {{Main|Adverse health effects from lunar dust exposure}} A 2005 NASA study listed 20 risks that required further study before humans should commit to a human Mars expedition, and ranked "dust" as the #1 challenge. The report urged study of its mechanical properties, corrosiveness, grittiness, and effect on electrical systems. Most scientists think the only way to answer the questions definitively is by returning samples of Martian soil and rock to Earth well before launching any astronauts.<ref name=Dirt/>
Although that report addressed Martian dust, the concerns are equally valid concerning lunar dust. The dust found on the lunar surface could cause harmful effects on any manned outpost technology and crew members: * Darkening of surfaces, leading to a considerable increase in [[radiative heat transfer]]; * Abrasive nature of the dust particles may rub and wear down surfaces through friction; * Negative effect on coatings used on gaskets to seal equipment from space, optical lenses, solar panels, and windows as well as wiring; * Possible damage to an astronaut's lungs, nervous, and cardiovascular systems.
The principles of astronautical hygiene should be used to assess the risks of exposure to lunar dust during exploration on the Moon's surface and thereby determine the most appropriate measures to control exposure. These may include removing the spacesuit in a three-stage airlock, "vacuuming" the suit with a magnet<ref>Professor Larry Taylor, Director of the Planetary Geosciences Institute at the University of Tennessee</ref> before removal, and using local exhaust ventilation with a high–efficiency particulate filter to remove dust from the spacecraft's atmosphere.<ref>Dr. J. R. Cain – "The application of astronautical hygiene to protect the health of astronauts", UK Space Biomedicine Association Conference 2009, Downing College, University of Cambridge</ref>
The harmful properties of lunar dust are not well known. However, based on studies of dust found on Earth, it is expected that exposure to lunar dust will result in greater risks to health both from direct exposure (acute) and if exposure is over time (chronic). This is because lunar dust is more chemically reactive and has larger surface areas composed of sharper jagged edges than Earth dust.<ref>Dr. John R. Cain, "Moon dust - a danger to lunar explorers", Spaceflight, Vol. 52, February 2010, pp. 60–65</ref> If the chemical reactive particles are deposited in the lungs, they may cause respiratory disease. Long-term exposure to the dust may cause a more serious respiratory disease similar to [[silicosis]]. During lunar exploration, the astronauts' spacesuits will become contaminated with lunar dust. The dust will be released into the atmosphere when the suits are removed. The methods used to mitigate exposure will include providing high air recirculation rates in the airlock, the use of a "Double Shell Spacesuit", the use of dust shields, the use of high–grade magnetic separation, and the use of solar flux to sinter and melt the regolith.<ref>Dr. John R. Cain, "Lunar dust: the hazard and astronaut exposure risks", Earth, Moon, Planets DOI 10.1007/s11038-010-9365-0 October 2010</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2006/pdf/2193.pdf|title=Micro-Morphology And Toxicological Effects Of Lunar Dust|accessdate=8 March 2007|last=Park|first=J.S.|author2=Y. Liu|author3=K. D. Kihm|author4=L. A. Taylor|publisher=Lunar and Planetary Science XXXVII (2006)|quote=The particle size distribution of the lunar dust from Apollo 17 sample 77051 has been determined using SEM imaging analysis. The size-distribution data features an approximate Gaussian distribution with a single mode at around 300-nm. The reactivation surface area of highly porous “Swiss-cheese” particles is about 26% higher than a sphere. The morphologies of dust grains have been classified based upon their four types: 1) spherical; 2) angular blocks; 3) glass shards; and 4) irregular (ropey or Swiss-cheese). These data will assist the medical researchers in their studies of the toxicological effects of inhalation of lunar dust by humans.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Kelly|last=Young|title=Lint rollers may collect dangerous Moon dust|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn11326-lint-rollers-may-collect-dangerous-moon-dust.html|publisher=[[New Scientist]]|date=6 March 2007|accessdate=17 February 2008|quote=While hailed as a potential source of oxygen and metals, Moon dust is a concern because doctors fear the smallest grains could lodge in astronauts' lungs, possibly causing long-term health effects.}}</ref>
===Present availability=== The Apollo astronauts brought back some 360 kilograms (800 pounds) of lunar rocks from six landing sites. Although this material has been isolated in vacuum-packed bottles, it is now unusable for detailed chemical or mechanical analysis—the gritty particles deteriorated the knife-edge [[indium]] seals of the vacuum bottles; air has slowly leaked in. Every sample brought back from the moon has been contaminated by Earth’s air and humidity. The dust has acquired a patina of rust, and, as a result of bonding with terrestrial water and oxygen molecules, its chemical reactivity is long gone. The chemical and electrostatic properties of the soil no longer match what future astronauts will encounter on the moon.<ref name=Dirt/>
Moon dust-contaminated items finally became available to the public in 2014, when the US government approved<ref>[http://www.collectspace.com/news/news-092612a.html ''New Law says astronauts can keep (or sell) their space artifacts.'']</ref> the sale of private material owned, and collected, by astronauts. Since then only one item has been produced for sale with genuine moon dust collected after the item spent over 32 hours on the Moon. A luggage strap, exposed to the elements of the Moon for 32 hours, a piece of Charles "Pete" Conrad's spacesuit on the Apollo 12 mission, was sold by his estate to a private purchaser at auction.<ref>[http://www.collectspace.com/news/news-042314a-astronaut-alanbean-moon-auction.html ''Apollo 12 astronaut's mementos up for auction] 23 April 2014</ref> In 2017 lunar soil collected by [[Neil Armstrong]] in 1969 was put up for auction.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2017-07-13/moon-dust-collected-by-neil-armstrong-to-be-sold-at-auction/|title=Moon dust collected by astronaut Neil Armstrong to be sold at auction|work=[[ITV News]]|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en}}</ref> While many jewelry- and watch-makers claim their product contains "moon dust", the products only contain pieces of, or dust from, meteorites believed to have originated from the Moon.
==See also== {{portal|Moon}} *[[Helium-3]] - section [[Helium-3#Extraction from extraterrestrial sources|Extraction from extraterrestrial sources]] discusses its potential use and occurrence in the Moon *[[Moon rock]] *[[Lunar regolith simulant]] *[[Sodium tail of the Moon]]
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Lunar soil}} *[http://www.lpi.usra.edu/lunar/surface/carrier_lunar_soils.pdf Geotechnical Properties of Lunar Soil] *[http://www.lpi.usra.edu/science/kring/lunar_exploration/briefings/lunar_soil_physical_properties.pdf Parameters of Lunar Soils] Lunar and Planetary Institute *[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/04/090417161508.htm Discovered After 40 Years: Moon Dust Hazard Influenced By Sun's Elevation]
{{The Moon}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lunar Soil}} [[Category:Lunar science]] [[Category:Soil]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Regolith]]

{{Infobox lake |name = Madum Lake |image = MadumLakeClear.JPG |caption = Water in Madum Lake in 2011. The lake's extremely pure and clear water supports a number of rare [[aquatic plant]]s, including certain species of ''[[Lobelia]]''. |image_bathymetry = |caption_bathymetry = |location = [[Rebild Municipality]], [[Mariagerfjord Municipality]], Denmark <!--{{coord|56.802|9.933|type:waterbody_region:DK|display=title}}--> |coords = {{coord|56.037|9.79|type:waterbody_region:DK|display=inline,title}} |type = [[Kettle hole]] |inflow = |outflow = |catchment = |basin_countries = |length = |width = |Total area = |area = {{convert|2.04|km2|mi2}} |max-depth = {{convert|7.5|m|ft}} |shore = |elevation = {{convert|36|m|ft}} |depth = {{convert|3|m|ft}} |volume = |residence_time = |islands = |cities = [[Skørping]], [[Astrup, Mariagerfjord|Astrup]] }} '''Madum Lake''' ([[Danish language|Danish]]: ''Madum Sø'') is the largest lake in the [[Himmerland]] peninsula of [[Jutland]], [[Denmark]]. The lake covers an area of {{convert|2.04|km2}}, and has a depth of {{convert|7.5|m|ft}} at its deepest point.<ref name=MadumSo/> It is both an important [[bird sanctuary]] and a popular bathing spot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visitdenmark.com/international/en-gb/menu/turist/oplevelser/aktiviteter/aktiviteterproduktside/gdk007871/madum-soe.htm?WBCMODE=Pr'%22&CallerUrl=1|title=Madum Sø|publisher=VisitDenmark.com|accessdate=24 October 2011}}</ref>
==Formation and surroundings== Madum Lake most likely developed out of a [[glacial]] [[kettle hole]] – a hollow formed by the melting of glacial ice left by the [[Quaternary ice age]].<ref name=MadumSo/> The lake formerly lay in [[heathland]], but it is now located in [[Rebild Municipality]], and is surrounded by the [[Rold Skov]] forest. To the north of the lake is a narrow forested belt, with [[birch]] as the dominant tree species. In the forest, common [[passerine]] birds dominate, along with [[buzzard]]s, [[goshawk]]s, [[sparrowhawk]]s, [[long-eared owl]]s, [[tawny owl]]s, [[black woodpecker]]s, [[European Green Woodpecker|green woodpecker]]s and [[raven]]s. In winter months, [[whooper swan]]s and [[merganser]] ducks can be seen around the lake.<ref name=MadumSo/>
Madum Lake and the surrounding forest are partly owned by three private interests – Lindenborg Gods, Nørlund and Willestrup Estate – with 25% of the forest falling under state ownership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visitrebild.dk/international/en-gb/menu/turist/inspiration/naturoplevelser/roldskov/roldskov.htm|title=The forest Rold Skov|publisher=VisitDenmark.com|accessdate=11 September 2012}}</ref> There is public access, and it is possible to walk around the lake on a marked route. Public fishing and boating on the lake is prohibited. At the lake's eastern shore is a visitor parking space, from which extends a marked route to and around the Long Marsh – a large, well-preserved [[bog]] in the forest to the east.
==Ecology and conservation== Madum Lake is part of a [[Natura 2000]] protected area (no. 18)<ref>[http://www.naturstyrelsen.dk/Naturbeskyttelse/Natura2000/Natura_2000_planer/Se_Planerne/001_125/18_Rold_Skov.htm "18 Rold Skov, Lindenborg Ådal og Madum Sø"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222133724/http://www.naturstyrelsen.dk/Naturbeskyttelse/Natura2000/Natura_2000_planer/Se_Planerne/001_125/18_Rold_Skov.htm |date=2014-02-22 }}. Danish Nature Agency {{da icon}}. Retrieved 19 February 2014.</ref> that also includes the forest of Rold Skov and the river valley of Lindenborg Ådal.<ref>[http://miljoegis.mim.dk/cbkort?profile=miljoegis_naturplaner2011 "Interactive GIS Map of Denmark"]. Danish Ministry of the Environment. 2011. Retrieved 19 February 2014.</ref> The protected area covers a total of {{convert|8,748|ha|km2}}, and is also protected under the EU [[Habitats Directive]] as a bird sanctuary.<ref name=no18>[http://www.naturstyrelsen.dk/NR/rdonlyres/0A6DE24C-1264-4BBD-81AB-09F558E8E07C/0/018Plan.pdf "Rold Skov, Lindenborg Ådal and Madum Lake - Natura 2000 area no. 18" (PDF)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222133728/http://www.naturstyrelsen.dk/NR/rdonlyres/0A6DE24C-1264-4BBD-81AB-09F558E8E07C/0/018Plan.pdf |date=2014-02-22 }}. Danish Ministry of the Environment {{da icon}}. Retrieved 19 February 2014.</ref>
===Birds=== Madum Lake is a [[bird sanctuary]] of international importance,<ref name=MadumSo>{{cite web|url=http://www.dofbasen.dk/IBA/lokalitet.php?lokid=3|title=Madum Sø|publisher=Dofbasen.dk|language=Danish|accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> and is designated as area F3 under the EU Habitats Directive.<ref name=no18/> It serves as a stopover for [[Goldeneye (duck)|goldeneye]] and [[tufted duck]]s, and to a lesser extent, [[mallard]]s. In the spring and autumn, [[osprey]]s forage on the lake's population of [[Esox|pike]] and [[perch]]. Madum Lake furthermore serves as an important breeding site for birds, hosting the nests of [[great crested grebe]]s, [[mute swan]]s and [[coot]]s.<ref name=MadumSo/>
===Threats and concerns=== Madum Lake has been declared a "Lobelia-lake", after the plant ''[[Lobelia dortmanna]]'', indicating very high water quality.<ref name=MadumSo/> However, there is evidence that, in recent years, the [[ecosystem]] of the lake has been stressed by outside pollution, including airborne [[nitrogen]] from agricultural activities and the more direct influence of hundreds of bathers in summer. A clear sign of this stress is seen in late summer in the form of [[algal blooms]], and the lake's [[Reed (plant)|reed]]-covered headlands have widened in recent years.<ref name=MadumSo/> The lake's waters reportedly remain very clear, but are increasingly acidic and nutrient-poor.<ref name=MadumSo/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.visitrebild.dk/NR/rdonlyres/5987C813-C32E-4009-B067-46BCEFC07DD8/0/madumsoeoglangmosenkort.pdf Danish-language map of the lake and its surroundings (PDF)] from Visitrebild.dk
